The JUNGLE as everyone pretty much called it was huge! Thousands of
acres a=
ll around with trees reaching up over one hundred feet into the
air like ta=
ll green spires reaching ever higher into the skies,
supported by thick pow=
erful trunks and supporting power of the
neighboring trees.

At first trave=
l was easy as WHEELIE followed a trail of devastation
and deforestation. It=
 was as if a stampede of hundreds of large
animals fled the jungle, crashin=
g into trees and stripping foliage as
they traveled. The result of which wa=
s a wide open and relatively
smooth open path of travel several miles into =
the immense wooded area.
But as time passed and the miles built upon themse=
lves the impact of
the animal's passing become less and less noticeable, th=
e area itself
becoming ever darker from the trees high over head and the th=
ick
growth of brush. The ground was becoming more and more uneven as tree
r=
oots grew into the pathway. What was once a brightly lit area was now
much =
darker, looking like deep evening, even though the noonday sun
burned brigh=
tly over head, blocked by thge lush canopy of trees, that
only occasionally=
 let in shafts of sunlight light to break open the
growing darkness.

Even =
the smell of things was beginning to change. The earth smell of
decomposing=
 leaves and animal waste could be smelled. Not necessarily
a bad smell, but=
 one that reminded you of the richness of the soil
that was being moved acr=
oss.

WHEELIE employing all the skills and experience at his disposal was
a=
ble to make his way in through the uneven and sometimes broken
ground, the =
jungle floor was perhaps among the most inhospitable to
wheeled vehicles th=
at most of the Earth at this time had to offer.
Lattice works of roots and =
foliage got caught in tires, the brush
having the annoying habit of blockin=
g sight and hiding nasty ravines
and holes and twisted turns. Branches and =
roots jutted out at strange
angles threatening to stab into more sensative =
and vulnerable
undersides and tires.

The sounds of the jungle was all arou=
nd WHEELIE, animals chattered at
him from the ground, as others hanging hig=
h in the trees looked down
at the strange orange conveyance that dared trav=
el through demesne.
There were signs of life all around him - The catcalls =
of other
animals, even a few roars in the distance of large predatory beast=
s.
Trees and branches moved strangely as if something indiscernible was
mov=
ing among them even if the author of the movement could not itself
be readi=
ly seen.

Then there was the eerie feeling of being watched. It was a feeli=
ng
that settled upon someone slowly at first. Perhaps a sound that didn=92t=

repeat itself or a movement than stopped when you did. Maybe it was
just a=
 gut feeling that somewhere out in the density of the foliage,
in the darke=
st shadows something was out there, and it was peering at
you, considering =
you.

It was into this maze of tree and wood, sounds and smells that WHEELI=
E
was driving, covered in muck and weaving past trees that were as large
ar=
ound as he was long. And yet despite all of that, there was a
strange sort =
of barely discernable path that led further and further
into the jungle int=
erior, meandering at times and yet always present.
.

OOC: For anyone that =
wants to fly in, you will find that you cannot
see the jungle floor, at lea=
st the section that Wheelie is in. You can
see the devastation that he foll=
owed in, but after a few miles it
fades and the jungle growth takes over. A=
ny smells or sounds he would
give off would be muffled by the dense foliage=
 and the ambient sounds
and smells of the jungle. In short he would be near=
ly impossible to
find anyone on the forest floor from the air unless you fi=
nd one of
the infrequent clearings. If you need a more aerial description o=
f the
place I can describe that in a different post. Just let me know
